title: Disney World Skyliner gondola breaks down leaving visitors 'stuck for two hours'
text:

Disney World's new Skyliner gondola has reportedly broken down, with guests saying they've been stuck in midair for more than two hours.

The ride in Orlando, Florida, only opened for business on September 29 but was attended by emergency services tonight after the apparent malfunction.

Reedy Creek Fire Service dispatched cherry pickers to help evacuate people stuck inside the gondola pods.

Disney blogger MiceChat claims one cabin jumped the cable leaving, which led to five cabins bumping into each other.

It is unclear if anyone is injured.

The Skyliner is a new way for visitors to travel around the Disney World site, with a number of pods themed around popular favourites like Toy Story and Star Wars.

The ride at Epcot also sees the cabins go over the Bay Lake.

Images have circulated showing the rescue mission over the water with zip-lines used to take people to safety.

Disney fans stuck on the ride took to Twitter this evening to plead with the park to provide some infomation.

One posted: "Hello?! We’ve been trapped in the sky on the Gondolas for an hour with no explanation what’s going on???? #disneyskyliner

Another wrote: "Been stuck on the new #disneyskyliner for an HOUR now this is insane!!! #disney #skyliner they aren’t communicating with us at all about what’s going on".

Guest GoodeDisneyDays tweeted: "Still stuck on the skyliner. (2 hours now). Thanks for the updates of what was going on since Disney has yet to tell us anything. Hoping everyone who was involved with the accident are not hurt.

Visitor Aaron Murray posted: "While being stuck for 2.5 hours has been rough, the occasional LOUD messages from the Skyliner is enough to put you slightly on edge. I understand protocol, but the repeated messages are similar to Chinese water torture techniques at this point."

Guests have been instructed to use the emergency kits that are located under the benches inside the gondolas.

Mirror Online have contacted Disney for comment.
description: The ride, in Orlando, Florida, only opened for business six days ago but guests have been posting images of it being evacuated
